label: Letter 2 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, March 11, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing the location of their new office building, the downfall of their favorite beach club, the Outrigger, and his task for the day of watching film to learn how to identify different ships and planes.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing the location of their new office building, the downfall of their favorite beach club, the Outrigger, and his task for the day of watching film to learn how to identify different ships and planes.

metadata.label: Access Note

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Dear Gertie, 
I suppose you are back from the plantation by now and
full of news of the old nlace and the troubles or beauties that
impressed you there. I am so interested to hear and hope you will
give me the low down before you forget your first impression and
only remember the nice things that happened.
It is such a lovely and suny day here. Spring is in the
air if such a thing is possible in a place where the temperature rarely
goes below seventy. Nevertheless something must be in the air because
I am yawning and stretching and wishing there was I window that I could
e look out of at the green trees. However I think we will be going up
to our new building in about three weeks and then we will have the
most lovely view of pearl harbor and the sea beyond. It will be very
nice to leave the dust and noise of the navy yard behind and get up
on the hill where the admirals live and there is nothing to do but
sleep and enjoy onesself the whole day through.
The outrigger club has fallen into disr[epute] with Morris :nd
I. For some reason the meals have become very cold and the food terrible.
What is it that makes a place go up an  down I wonder. For a while it
was so crowded that it was almost impossible to get a table without knowing
the manager and giving him a new set of tires whenver you went. Now
the place is almost deserted and there is no one playing volley ball
or lying in the su . I suppose withih a few weeks it will all come back
and be as croided as ever, and that the only trouble is that people are
fickle and have decided that it is no longer the place to go. If they
would only serve hot food again I would be delighted and would not care
whether an one ever came again .
Today I have been checking over all the movie film that
is sent to us for the purpose of learning how to identify ships and
planes. It is wonderful how things are shipped that you do not wish
and you can write and send cables without ever seeing the things that
you need very badly . That however isthe way with everything whether
hyou are in the Na vy or not so it does not matter a great deal.
I am enclosing some picutres that mean nothing as far as
I can see, but as you asked for picutres here they are. I still have
not been able to take a picutre of Morris and he of course cannot take
one of me, but we are still trying.
With all my love. I told Smells to continue sending flowers
to you but did not send him the cards in time to enclose them so if
you get any flowers without cards you may know it is from me.
Sidney
